Graphical abstract Metal oxides structures, formed by ordered self-assembling of crystalline nanoparticles aggregates, are attracting growing attention in fields such as catalysis or solar cells. The properties of these structures are influenced not only by their morphology and nanoparticles composition but also by the assembled particles boundaries. In order to determine the influence of these boundaries on the structures properties, the present investigation has been devoted to study the characteristics of anatase nanoparticles boundaries in titania aggregates prepared by TiCl4 hydrolysis at low temperature. Proton magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance and high resolution transmission electron microscopy show that these samples mainly contain amorphous TiO2 strongly bound to specific faces of anatase particles. This amorphous titania-mediated attachment induces the ordered self-assembling of the anatase particles, with favored formation of mesopores in the nanoparticles boundaries. Photocatalytic degradation of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol in water, test reaction used as a method to get information on the boundaries properties, indicates that the mesoporous amorphous TiO2 offers active sites for the alcohol catalytic partial oxidation, but it strongly hampers inter-particles electron transfer. These effects, characteristic of amorphous oxide chain morphology, can be expected when low dispersed dopants or promoters are incorporated to metal oxides. Keywords Amorphous titania Anatase nanoparticles boundaries: inter-particles electron transfer 4-Methoxybenzyl alcohol partial oxidation HRTEM 1H-MAS-NMR 1 Introduction Metal oxide structures, formed by ordered self-assembling of crystalline nanoparticles with morphology such as those of nanowires, nanotubes or three dimensionally ordered macroporous structures, are attracting great attention. This attraction is motivated by their potential application in fields such as catalysis, photocatalysis, electromagnetics, photoelectronics, sensors, photonic crystals, solar cells, or battery electrodes [1–3]. The different preparation methods of these structures offer the exciting prospect of tailoring the crystallization in order to create nanostructured materials with well-defined sizes and shapes as well as improved physical and chemical properties [1–3]. Indeed, nanoparticles preparations in mild conditions favor the formation not only of highly defective crystalline particles but also of amorphous phases whose presence, though often acknowledged, rarely has been taken into account [4]. In this case, the nanoparticles properties can be influenced by the characteristics of crystalline and amorphous components, the structure morphology, and also by the less-studied aggregated nanoparticles boundaries. The nanoparticles boundaries of titania aggregates, prepared by hydrothermal treatment of precursors obtained by sol–gel methods and constituted by anatase and a small amount of amorphous titania, have been previously studied by 1H-MAS-NMR [5,6]. This investigation allowed to determine the characteristics of water and hydroxyls protons on the surface of both sample components. The assignments indicated that water-mediated H-bonding of bridging and terminal hydroxyls on specific faces of contiguous anatase nanoparticles induced the particles ordered self-assembling. This aggregation effect stabilized the mediating water and contributed to limit the growth of the particles crystal size. This effect reached a maximum when the anatase crystal size was around 6nm [5], due to the special acidic and basic strength of their bridging and terminal hydroxyls. The removal of water and hydroxyls by outgassing the samples at temperatures higher than 473K should lead, first, to formation of low-coordinated Ti4+ and O2− ions in the boundaries of contiguous anatase particles. In this situation, the electrostatic forces induced by the low-coordinated ions should keep attached the anatase particles [3]. The increasing defects concentration in the anatase surface with decreasing crystal size increasingly strengthens the acidic and basic character of the bridging and terminal hydroxyls, so favoring inter-particles hydroxyls proton exchange and facilitating the acid-basic hydroxyls reaction. This reaction should lead to formation of Ti–O–Ti bonds between low-coordinated Ti4+ and bridging O2− ions in the boundaries of contiguous anatase particles when the water formed by the hydroxyls reaction is removed. This particles attachment is stronger than the one originated by electrostatic forces. The strengthening of acidic and basic character is particularly marked in the hydroxyls of low condensed amorphous titania chains [7]. These chains, which have been described as staggered Ti–O octahedral associations [8,9], form the main component of samples prepared by TiCl4 hydrolysis and subsequent aging in strongly acidic suspension [10]. The amorphous titania hydroxyls react first with the hydroxyls of other amorphous titania chains, leading to the chains condensation, but also with the hydroxyls of anatase nanoparticles, inducing strong bonds among anatase particles. Recent works on the photocatalytic oxidation of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol [11,12], a process occurring with partial oxidation and mineralization reactions in parallel, showed that the selectivity to partial oxidation product was markedly higher using home prepared titania nanoparticles than commercial ones, indicating that the surfaces of these two types of photocatalysts were significantly different. Characterization studies of these titania nanoparticles [12], home prepared by TiCl4 hydrolysis at room temperature and aging of the resulting aqueous suspension at 373K for 0.5 or 2h, showed that the increasing aging time improved the sample crystallization. The crystalline components of these nanoparticles were anatase and rutile, less defective in sample aged 2h than in the 0.5h one; amorphous titania, however, was the predominant component with percentage as high as 93–94%. In titania nanoparticles prepared by precipitation at low temperature, the coexistence and arrangement of crystalline and amorphous phases play an important role in determining the bulk and superficial characteristics of the samples and eventually their activity performances. On these grounds, the present investigation has been focused on studying the mechanism by which the anatase crystals attach together and on the role played by amorphous phases on that process. Therefore, we have studied the morphology and texture of amorphous titania-rich samples with respect to the BDH TiO2 sample (commercial anatase, used as reference, with predominantly crystalline content). A comparative HRTEM and 1H-MAS NMR study of amorphous-rich and amorphous-poor samples has been carried out to determine the characteristics of the self-assembled anatase nanoparticles boundaries. The influence of these boundaries on the samples activity performance has been checked by testing the titania samples for the photocatalytic oxidation of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol in water. Indeed, TiO2 is one of the most popular semiconductors for applications in photocatalysis due to its quantum efficiency, chemical inertness, and photostability [13–15]. The photocatalytic oxidation of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol in aqueous titania suspensions [11,12] is a well-known process; it occurs through two parallel pathways: (i) partial oxidation to the corresponding aldehyde (p-anisaldehyde) and (ii) complete oxidation to CO2 (mineralization) through a series of intermediates that do not desorb to the bulk of solution. The activity performance of the tested samples has been evaluated by determining the following quantitative parameters: (i) the kinetic constant of the alcohol disappearance rate (a parameter related to the sample bulk properties); and (ii) the reaction selectivity toward the partial oxidation product (a parameter related to the sample surface properties). Photoactivity and selectivity have been used as a tool to determine differences in the catalytic active sites present on the samples and the influence of the different type of anatase particles boundaries on the samples catalytic performance. 2 Materials and methods The synthesis by hydrolysis of TiO2 samples started with the preparation of a precursor solution [10] at room temperature by slowly dropping 5cm3 of TiCl4 (Fluka 98%) into a magnetically stirred beaker containing 50cm3 of deionized water. After that, the beaker was closed and the mixing was prolonged for 12h at room temperature, eventually obtaining a clear solution. After the TiCl4 controlled hydrolysis, the solution was transferred to a round-bottom flask having a Graham condenser on its top. The flask was put in boiling water for 0.5 or 2h to obtain white suspensions; at the end of this treatment, the suspensions were dried at 323K in a rotovapor to obtain powdered photocatalysts, denoted respectively by TiO2·HL0.5 and TiO2·HL2. In one preparative run of TiO2·HL0.5 sample, commercial TiO2 (BDH) was added to the solution before its transfer to the flask; the amount of added TiO2 powder was chosen in order to have a 50:50 w:w BDH-TiO2·HL0.5 mixture. For the sample preparation by hydrothermal treatment, amorphous titania precursors were synthesized from titanium isopropoxide by sol–gel method [5]. The anatase-rich samples were obtained by heating 0.2g of the gel in a Teflon-lined autoclave vessel with 15ml of H2O and 10ml of 2-propanol at 373K (indicated as TiO2·HT373) or with 12ml of H2O and 13ml of 2-propanol at 423K (indicated as TiO2·HT423). XRD patterns were recorded at 1°min−1 in a Philips Panalytical X’Pert MPD diffractometer using the Cu Kα radiation. For structural refinements, the PowderCell 2.4 program was used. Prior to the structure refinements, a pattern matching without structural model was performed to obtain suitable profile parameters. Then, the structural model was refined with the Rietveld method keeping constant profile parameters. The crystallinity of all the samples was evaluated following the procedure reported by Jensen et al. [16]. XRD diffractograms were recorded for mixtures of TiO2 and CaF2 (50%, w/w) and the areas of the 100% peaks of anatase {101} and CaF2 {220} were determined. By comparing the ratio between the areas of these two peaks to the ratio obtained by using the pure phases (1.25 for anatase), the amount of crystalline and amorphous phases present in the samples was determined. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed by using a Perkin–Elmer equipment (model STA 6000). The samples were put in an open Pt crucible and heated at 5Kmin−1 up to 870K in a N2 flow of 20cm3 min−1. 1H NMR spectra were recorded after π/2 radiofrequency pulse irradiations at 400.13MHz in an AVANCE 400 (Bruker) spectrometer (B 0 =9.4T). In MAS-NMR experiments, samples were spun at 10kHz around an axis inclined 54°44′ with respect to the magnetic field. The number of scans was 100 and the time between successive experiments 5s. A conventional vacuum line (residual pressure: 1×10−4 Torr) was used to evacuate the samples. To preserve the evacuation conditions, the rotors were filled under nitrogen atmosphere inside a globe box. The spectral deconvolution was carried out with the Winfit (Bruker) software package. Chemical shift values were referred to the TMS signal. The NMR lines intensities were referred to the line originated by the rotor cap used. TEM micrographs were obtained by a JEOL-JEM 3000F electron microscope operating at 300kV. In all cases, the sample was suspended in butanol and a drop of the suspension was deposited over a copper grid coated with a holey carbon support film. SEM images were obtained using a FEG microscope (Philips, Quanta 200F) operating at 20kV. To perform the reactivity experiments, a cylindrical Pyrex batch photoreactor with immersed lamp, containing 0.5l of aqueous suspension, was used. The photoreactor was provided with ports in its upper section for the inlet and outlet of oxygen and for sampling. A magnetic stirrer guaranteed a satisfactory suspension of the photocatalyst and the homogeneity of the reacting mixture. A 125W medium pressure Hg lamp (Helios Italquartz, Italy), axially positioned within the photoreactor, was cooled by water circulating through a Pyrex thimble; the temperature of the suspension was 300±2K. The radiation energy impinging on the suspension, measured at 360nm with a radiometer UVX Digital, had an average value of 9.5mWcm−2. For all the runs, the initial 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol concentration was ca. 1mM. NaOH 1M solution was used to adjust the initial pH to 7. The amount of catalyst chosen for all the photocatalytic runs was of 0.2gl−1; in these conditions, the resulting suspensions were able to absorb 65% of the impinging radiation. This choice guaranteed not only that all catalyst particles were well irradiated but also that all the runs were carried out at equal irradiation conditions, so allowing the correct comparison of activity results. Measurements of the transmitted light in the presence of the suspension were carried out by using the radiometer above described. Before switching on the lamp, pure oxygen was bubbled into the suspension for 30min. at room temperature to reach the thermodynamic equilibrium. Adsorption of alcohol under dark conditions was always quite low, i.e., ca. 5%. During the runs, samples of the reacting suspension were withdrawn at fixed time intervals and immediately filtered through a 0.45μm hydrophilic membrane (HA, Millipore) before being analyzed. The identification and quantitative determination of species present in the reacting suspension was performed by means of a Beckman Coulter HPLC (System Gold 126 Solvent Module and 168 Diode Array Detector), equipped with a Luna 5μ Phenyl-Hexyl column (250mm long×2 mmi.d.), using Sigma–Aldrich standards. Retention times and UV spectra of the compounds were compared with those of standards. The eluent consisted of: 17.5% acetonitrile, 17.5% methanol, 65% 40mM KH2PO4 aqueous solution. Retention times for 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol and p-anisaldehyde are 8.7 and 17.1min, respectively. TOC analyses were carried out by using a 5000 A Shimadzu TOC analyzer. All used chemicals were provided by Sigma–Aldrich with a purity >99.0%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts features The XRD patterns of TiO2·HL0.5 (Fig. 1 ) reveal that only the anatase phase is present, peaks at 2θ =25.58°, 38.08°, 48.08°, 54.58°, all being assignable to anatase. An increase in the boiling time to 2h determines a better crystallinity of the sample and the appearance of rutile phase with peaks at 2θ =27.58° and 36.58°. The 1H-MAS NMR spectra of the hydrated samples (Fig. 2 ) show that their main component, line W attributed to strongly H-bonded adsorbed water [5,6], appears at 5.6 and 6.7ppm, respectively. This line width is of 0.9, 1.7, 3.7 and 5.3ppm in TiO2·HT423, TiO2·HT373, TiO2·HL2 and TiO2·HL0.5 spectra, respectively. The chemical shift of line W in the TiO2·HL2 and TiO2·HL0.5 spectra is higher than in the other ones. This feature indicates that highly mobile adsorbed water that is averaging the chemical shift of most samples hydroxyls is interacting with the bridging hydroxyls of the amorphous titania component of TiO2·HL2 and TiO2·HL0.5 samples, and these hydroxyls being more acidic than those of TiO2·HT423 and TiO2·HT373 samples. The line W chemical shift of TiO2·HL2 and TiO2·HL0.5 samples spectra, close to that of hydronium cations protons, indicates the formation of H3O+ species. Meanwhile, the line-width variation is consistent with the different water H-bonding to hydroxyls in both types of samples. So, the very strong water H-bonding in TiO2·HT423 [6] induces a higher mobility giving a very narrow line W. However, the strong acidity of amorphous titania bridging hydroxyls in TiO2·HL2 and TiO2·HL0.5 samples facilitates their proton solvation, favoring the hydronium cations formation, hampering water H-bonding to bridging hydroxyls [5]. Thus, line W broadening in these spectra and, in lower degree, in that of TiO2·HT373 is induced by weakening the water H-bonding network. Evacuation at room temperature mainly produced the decrease and broadening of line W in the TiO2·HT373 and TiO2·HT423 samples spectra (Fig. 2), indicating the removal of some weakly adsorbed water and a lower mobility of the remaining one. In contrast, the TiO2·HL2 and TiO2·HL0.5 spectra show, besides a more marked intensity decrease, the replacement of line W by a broad band at 8.1 and 7.6ppm respectively, as the main spectra component. This band is formed by two overlapped lines attributed to protons of strongly acidic amorphous titania bridging hydroxyls H-bonded to different species; its presence indicates that the removal of the highly mobile water induces the localization as amorphous titania bridging hydroxyls of protons that were solvated in the hydrated TiO2·HL2 and TiO2·HL0.5 samples. The chemical shift of the amorphous titania bridging hydroxyls lines decreases by increasing the suspension aging time from 0.5 to 2h, during the samples preparation. This decrease is due to the weakening of the amorphous titania bridging hydroxyls acidity by the amorphous titania chain condensation [7], probably because of the enhanced coordination of the amorphous titania low-coordinated Ti4+ cations. Evacuation at 373K produced the decrease in all samples spectra intensity, particularly evident in the TiO2·HT373 spectrum (Fig. 2). The removal of the water averaging the chemical shift of TiO2·HT373 hydroxyls let see the proton lines of anatase hydroxyls, isolated and exchanging protons with protonated species. This hydroxyl interaction led to the reaction of bridging and terminal hydroxyls of contiguous anatase particles when the sample was outgassed at 423K [5]. Though some of the water formed by this reaction remains coordinated to low-coordinated Ti4+ cations, most of it is removed, inducing the formation of low-coordinated Ti4+ cations and bridging O2− anions, facilitating their bonding with the formation of inter-particles Ti–O–Ti bonds. The coordinated water protons originate the broadest side-band pattern, with central component at around 6ppm in the TiO2·HT373 spectrum, with much lower intensity than in those of TiO2·HL2 and TiO2·HL0.5 samples. With respect to TiO2·HT373 and TiO2·HT423 samples, in TiO2·HL2 and TiO2·HL0.5 samples the removal of the water averaging the hydroxyls protons chemical shifts is easier and the intensity of the broad side-band patterns, attributed to water coordinated to low-coordinated Ti4+, is higher. These features are consistent with the enhanced proton exchange taking place in these samples due to the stronger acidic character of the bridging hydroxyls of amorphous titania chains. These hydroxyl interactions favor the reaction with terminal surface hydroxyls of anatase and of other amorphous titania chains. The more abundant low-coordinated Ti4+ cations in amorphous titania chains than in anatase particles favor the formation of a higher amount of coordinated water in the amorphous titania component. However, most of the generated water should be removed, favoring the Ti4+ cations bonding to bridging O2− anions, forming Ti–O–Ti bonds. These reactions lead to the amorphous titania chains condensation, forming amorphous titania species [17,18] with weakened acidic and basic hydroxyls [7] that cover the anatase particles surface. This surface layer of amorphous titania hinders the anatase crystal growth, and due to the favored reaction between amorphous titania chains hydroxyls, it facilitates the anatase particles aggregation. Taking into account that the strength of the hydroxyls acidic and basic character depends on the particular characteristics of anatase surface faces where they are located, the amorphous titania chains should more favorably bound to the anatase faces containing the most strongly acidic and basic hydroxyls, inducing an ordered aggregation. The NMR investigation allows to conclude that the strengthening of the particles bonding is particularly intense when amorphous titania chains are present, as observed in amorphous titania-rich samples [7]. Then, the amorphous titania hydroxyls react first with other amorphous titania chains hydroxyls, leading to the chains condensation, but also with anatase nanoparticles hydroxyls, inducing strong bonds between specific crystal planes of contiguous anatase nanoparticles. Both anatase particles bonding mechanisms limit the anatase crystal growth and favor their ordered self-assembling. The BET specific surface areas of TiO2·HL0.5, TiO2·HL2, and BDH TiO2 samples, calculated from their nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms, are reported in Table 1 ; of those are values 143, 195.6 and 9m2 g−1, respectively, correspond to their external surface areas and 53.1, 1.2 and 0m2 g−1 to their microporosity. The TiO2·HL0.5 pore volume was 0.305cm3 g−1 (micropore volume: 0.026cm3 g−1; average pore width: 6.5nm) and that of TiO2·HL2 was 0.273cm3 g−1 (micropore volume: ≈0cm3 g−1; average pore width: 5.6nm). Meanwhile, the pore area distribution curves (Fig. 3 ) show mainly microporosity (less than 4nm) and mesopores of 13nm for TiO2·HL0.5, low microporosity and mesopores of about 7nm for TiO2·HL2 and no porosity [19] for the BDH. The marked elimination of micropores after 2h of suspension aging, while the amorphous titania is being condensed and anatase particles improve their crystallinity, indicates that the microporosity, mainly associated with the presence of components with chain morphology, is originated by weakly condensed amorphous titania chains on the anatase surface. The decrease in the mesopores size is associated with amorphous titania chains condensation and desorption of water formed by reaction of amorphous titania chain hydroxyls in the inner contact zones of anatase particles during the condensation process. These effects are confirmed by the lower intensity and higher temperature of the water desorption peaks in the TiO2·HL2 TPD profile than in that of TiO2·HL0.5 (Fig. 4 ). The HRTEM images of TiO2·HL0.5 and TiO2·HL2 (Figs. 5 and 6 ) show spherical nanoparticles with mean diameter of 5nm, in agreement with the XRD results, and relatively narrow size distribution. Some particles exhibit crystalline domains showing sets of parallel lines, most of them with spacing of ∼0.352nm corresponding to {101} crystal planes of anatase. Some other particles appear covered by a rough layer, displaying worm-like features typical of amorphous oxides [20,21], heterogeneously distributed but mainly concentrated at the particles contact zones. The core of these particles, more abundant in TiO2·HL2 than in TiO2·HL0.5 images, is formed by anatase and/or rutile; however, structural planes of rutile could not be unambiguously identified, probably because they are covered by amorphous titania layers as a consequence of the particles agglomeration. Despite of the disorder, short-range ordered contrast patterns can be observed forming a whitish strip at the non-attached periphery of these particles. This strip decreasing width with increasing suspension aging time reflects the amorphous titania chains condensation. An indication of the amorphous titania presence is the detection of the diffuse rings in local fast Fourier transform (FFT) patterns of TiO2·HL0.5 and TiO2·HL2, which also display anatase diffraction peaks. The semicircle-like diffuse spots centered at ∼3.1Å in TEM patterns have been associated with chains of corner-sharing Ti–O–Ti bridges [22]. These short chains, with estimated size ranging from 5 to 12Å corresponding to 2–4 titania octahedra associations, can form bundles of staggered Ti–O octahedra [22] originating microporosity if weakly condensed. The observation of a more diffuse ring and the presence of two additional diffraction peaks in the TiO2·HL2 pattern than in that of TiO2·HL0.5 suggest a stronger amorphous titania chains condensation and the partial transformation of anatase into rutile with aging processes. The FFT of the anatase BDH reference is given in Fig. 7 . The HRTEM images also show that, by prolonging the suspension aging time from 0.5 to 2h, the particle aggregates size increases from 20 to 70nm, due to the coalescence of contiguous aggregates by reaction of amorphous titania hydroxyls at their periphery. In addition, the direction of the lattice fringes corresponding to the anatase {101} planes is the same in most TiO2·HL0.5 contiguous particles, due to the favored amorphous titania hydroxyls reaction with those of the anatase planes displaying the most acidic and basic hydroxyls. Those fringes, however, no longer appear parallel in the TiO2·HL2 images (Fig. 8 ). This modification of anatase lattice fringes direction has also been observed when anatase particles were calcined at 723K [20], being attributed to the anatase particles rotation as result of shear stresses produced by amorphous titania at the particles contact zones. In the case of TiO2·HL0.5 and TiO2·HL2 anatase particles, the shear stress producing their rotation, considered the first step for anatase–rutile transformation, can be attributed to the amorphous titania chains condensation on the anatase surface, mainly, at the particles contact zones. The markedly lower temperature required for the TiO2·HL0.5 and TiO2·HL2 anatase particles rotation indicates that the suspension acidity influences the anatase particles arrangement more strongly than thermal treatments. Besides worm-like features, the particles contact zones images show an enhanced formation of whitish and dark ones, with increasing suspension aging time. The simultaneous amorphous titania chain condensation, with increasing water removal and mesopores formation by prolonging the suspension aging time, indicates that these colored features correspond to voids and amorphous titania accumulation at the samples surface, produced by desorption of bulk water, formed by hydroxyls reactions during the amorphous titania chains condensation. 3.2 Activity performance The influence of amorphous titania on the activity performance of samples has been checked by testing the photocatalytic oxidation of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol in aqueous suspension. This reaction proceeds through two parallel pathways [23,24] depending on the type of photocatalyst surface sites where 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol is adsorbed: partial oxidation to p-anisaldehyde and total oxidation to CO2. No oxidation of alcohol was observed in the absence of irradiation, catalyst or oxygen for runs carried out under the same experimental conditions used for the photocatalytic ones. For all the samples, the adsorption of the aromatic alcohol was quite low and their irradiation did not produce photoadsorption nor photodesorption [25], so that it may be confidently assumed that the adsorption kinetics played the same role in all the reactivity runs. The results of representative runs of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol photocatalytic degradation are reported in Fig. 9 . For all the reactivity runs, the alcohol degradation data showed to obey first-order kinetics with respect to alcohol concentration, expressed by the following equation: (1) - 1 S dN dt = - V S dC dt = kC in which S is the catalyst surface area, N the 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol moles, t the irradiation time, V the suspension volume, C the 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol concentration, and k the kinetic constant that takes into account both the mineralization and the partial oxidation processes. Owing that the disappearance rate is normalized with respect to the catalyst surface area, the kinetic constant k of Eq. (1) is independent of the surface area of catalyst. Moreover, even if the kinetic constant depends on many operative parameters such as the photoreactor setup, the light intensity field [26] inside the irradiated suspension, the substrate and catalyst amount, it is justified to take the k value as a reliable parameter for ordering the intrinsic activity of catalysts owing to the fact that all the runs were carried out at equal irradiation and reaction conditions, the only difference being the ratio between amorphous and crystalline phases of the catalysts. By fitting the integrated equation of Eq. (1) to the experimental C–t data, the values of k are obtained. The values of the kinetic constant, k, and the selectivity to p-anisaldehyde are reported in Table 1. The obtained k values are 2.73×10−6 and 3.24×10−6 mh−1 for TiO2·0.5h and TiO2·2h, respectively, indicating that TiO2·2h is more active toward 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol degradation. The ratio between partial oxidation reaction and mineralization decreases with increasing aging time of the catalysts suspensions. For TiO2·HL0.5 and TiO2·HL2, the selectivity to aldehyde decreases from 41.5% to 36.7% for a 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol conversion of 50%; however, this decrease is mainly determined by the increase in the mineralization rates, while the partial oxidation rates remain nearly constant. Meanwhile, the k and selectivity values obtained testing BDH anatase, at the same experimental conditions, are 8.45×10−5 mh−1 and only 6%, respectively. For equal absorbed photon flows, the increasing reaction rate of three samples with decreasing amorphous titania content indicates that the amorphous component, mainly concentrated at the anatase particles contact zones, hampers the photoreactivity by hindering the e−–h+ pairs mobility. This result underlines the important contribution of the inter-particles charge transfer in photocatalytic reactions, as demonstrated in a recent investigation on the influence of the intergrain boundaries on the electrons mobility in mesoporous TiO2 photoanodes [27]. This contribution is also important in heterogeneous catalysis when titanium dioxide is used as a support in synergistic effect with metals [28–31]; in this case, the enhancement of the TiO2 electric conductivity positively affects the catalytic activity. The lower reaction rate on TiO2·HL0.5 than on TiO2·HL2 indicates that the enhancement of the photocatalytic reaction is determined by: (i) the anatase crystallinity improvement, which eliminates crystalline defects, sites where photogenerated electrons and holes (the active species for photocatalysis) recombine; and (ii) the increase in amorphous titania chains condensation, which also increases the amorphous titania density at the contact zone of contiguous anatase particles. The reactivity results obtained with the BDH-TiO2·HL0.5 sample (see Table 1) confirm the previous considerations. For this sample, even if the TiO2·HL0.5 mesopores increase the specific surface area and the overall crystallinity is about four times higher than that of TiO2·HL0.5 and TiO2·HL2 samples, the values of kinetic constant and selectivity are very similar to those of TiO2·HL0.5 and TiO2·HL2 samples. As it may be seen from the SEM images reported in Fig. 10 , the TiO2·HL0.5 aggregates are almost totally covering the crystalline BDH particles so that the catalyst superficial features affecting the selectivity are predominantly those of TiO2·HL0.5 sample. Moreover, the contacts between the TiO2·HL0.5 particles and the BDH TiO2 ones, owing to the low temperature of the preparation conditions, strongly hinder the charges transfer from the crystalline anatase to the TiO2·HL0.5 ones, so that the higher reactivity of BDH TiO2 cannot be transferred to the amorphous-rich particles. The significantly lower selectivity to p-anisaldehyde on low defective anatase than on TiO2·HL0.5 and TiO2·HL2 samples indicates that amorphous titania at the anatase surface is mainly providing the active sites for 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol partial oxidation. These sites, where 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol is adsorbed on the catalyst through the alcoholic group with the aromatic ring plane perpendicular to the surface, probably are strongly basic amorphous titania terminal hydroxyls bounded to low-coordinated Ti4+ cations. These cations could limit the electron mobility by acting as photogenerated electron trapping sites in the grains boundaries [32,33]. The reaction of alcoholic groups with those hydroxyls, under UV irradiation, should lead first to water formation. The activation of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol molecules via the subtraction of hydrogen atoms from their alcohol group can facilitate the bonding of these carbon atoms with O2− anions of deprotonated amorphous titania bridging hydroxyls [34]. As those O2− anions are the favored sites for photogenerated holes trapping, the reaction of the adsorbed complex with radicals formed by UV irradiation in presence of oxygen molecules can lead toward the p-anisaldehyde formation. The lower selectivity to p-anisaldehyde on TiO2·HL2 than on TiO2·HL0.5 is consistent with the decreasing basic character of the amorphous titania terminal hydroxyls with increasing condensation of its chains. 4 Conclusions The reported results show that amorphous titania not only can limit the size of small TiO2 crystalline nanoparticles but also it can produce nanoparticles self-assemblings, with specific orientation, that induce the anatase–rutile transformation at low temperature and modify the particles surface and morphological properties. All these effects are mainly originated by the strong basic character of terminal hydroxyls of amorphous titania chains. These effects could also take place in other materials constituted by crystalline and amorphous oxides. The importance of these oxides can be particularly high in heterogeneous catalysis when, as very often it happens, catalysts formed by highly dispersed active oxides, promoters or dopants, supported on crystalline ones, are used. To our knowledge, however, the specific properties of the amorphous active oxide have never been considered to explain results of difficult interpretation. coredata.dc:description: Metal oxides structures, formed by ordered self-assembling of crystalline nanoparticles aggregates, are attracting growing attention in fields such as catalysis or solar cells. The properties of these structures are influenced not only by their morphology and nanoparticles composition but also by the assembled particles boundaries. In order to determine the influence of these boundaries on the structures properties, the present investigation has been devoted to study the characteristics of anatase nanoparticles boundaries in titania aggregates prepared by TiCl4 hydrolysis at low temperature. Proton magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance and high resolution transmission electron microscopy show that these samples mainly contain amorphous TiO2 strongly bound to specific faces of anatase particles. This amorphous titania-mediated attachment induces the ordered self-assembling of the anatase particles, with favored formation of mesopores in the nanoparticles boundaries. Photocatalytic degradation of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol in water, test reaction used as a method to get information on the boundaries properties, indicates that the mesoporous amorphous TiO2 offers active sites for the alcohol catalytic partial oxidation, but it strongly hampers inter-particles electron transfer. These effects, characteristic of amorphous oxide chain morphology, can be expected when low dispersed dopants or promoters are incorporated to metal oxides.
coredata.dc:title: The influence of the anatase nanoparticles boundaries on the titania activity performance

dcterms:subject.$: Anatase nanoparticles boundaries: inter-particles electron transfer
